prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context: In a study published by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. in Physica A 564 (2021), Figure 2 illustrates each social layer of a multi-layer network. The nodes in the network represent individuals, and the weighted connections indicate social contacts that could potentially lead to infection based on the probability values assigned to the edges (ranging from 0 to 1). The first layer focuses on home interactions, where groups of varying sizes are fully connected internally. These groups, derived from the distribution of Peruvian family sizes in 2009, are disconnected from each other, reflecting distinct family units. The size distribution considered in the study spans from families of 1 to 10 members, with probabilities assigned accordingly. Therefore the probability of a family having ten persons is the sum of the larger sizes, the details of this distribution are given in Table 1. The first layer is then created following the family size distribution and ensuring that each family has at least one adult. Fig. 2(a) shows the structure of such a layer built for a
post_context: . A significant portion of the population in any country engages in economic activities, necessitating interaction with others. Work is a crucial aspect of social relationships, especially during an epidemic. To simulate work connections, we propose a general layer involving individuals aged 18 to 59, representing 60% of Peru's population. Given the diverse job market, creating precise connection rules is challenging. We suggest a scenario with random groups ranging from 5 to 30 members, internally connected like the "home" layer. This setup, illustrated in Fig. 2(b) for n = 100, influences virus transmission based on edge weights, discussed in Section 3.1.1. Public transportation is vital in most cities but poses a high risk for epidemic spread due to constant movement. Our third layer simulates public transport, including 50% of the population, randomly sampled, with group sizes between 10 and 40, fully connected. In Peru, public transport utilization varies based on city size, with an average daily usage of 1.2 hours. We consider a population average participation rate of 50%, combining figures from capital and non-capital cities, in the "transports" layer.

prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context:
In the study conducted by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. (2021), a multi-layer network model is proposed to represent social interactions. The nodes in the network represent individuals and remain constant across different layers. Weighted connections between nodes indicate social contact that may lead to infection, with the edge weight representing the probability value within a range of 0 to 1.

The first layer of the network represents home interactions and consists of groups with varying sizes. These groups are internally fully connected but have no external connections, symbolizing individual families. The distribution of family sizes in Peru for the year 2010 is used to create these groups, with emphasis on ensuring that each family includes at least one adult. The structure of this layer for a population of 100 individuals is depicted in Fig. 2(a).

Additionally, a generic layer is introduced to reflect work interactions among individuals aged 18 to 59 years, encompassing 60% of the total population in Peru. Work activities are considered crucial in social relations and are particularly significant in the context of an epidemic.There is a wide variety of jobs and companies, therefore it is not trivial to create a connection rule that precisely reflects the real world. Here, we consider a common scenario with random groups of sizes around [5, 30], uniformly distributed, and internally connected (such as the ''home'' layer). An example of this layer is shown on Fig. 2(b), using
post_context: . In Section 3.1.1, we delve into how the transmission of the virus in a group with fully connected nodes is directly influenced by the edge weights. Public transportation systems, essential in most cities, are among the most crowded environments and are a key factor in the spread of an epidemic due to the constant movement of vehicles. Our proposed third layer represents these systems, catering to individuals who do not have access to personal vehicles. In Peru, the utilization of public transport varies depending on the city size, with 64.98% in capitals and 35.89% in other cities. On average, individuals in Peru spend around 1.2 hours daily using public transport. For our model, we consider a randomly sampled 50% of the population to be part of the "transports" layer, organized into random groups of sizes ranging from 10 to 40. Each group is fully connected to simulate real-world interactions. Source: http://g1.globo.com/bom-dia-peru/noticia/2015/02/peruanos-gastam-em-media-1h20-por-dia-em-transportes-publicos.html.

contents: location: rio de janeiro; time: march 25
author: enrique
pre_context: In a study published in Physica A, researchers analyzed the impact of various interventions on the progression of an epidemic, including changes in case numbers, death rates, and hospital bed occupancy. The study simulated a social network with initial infection probabilities and began the spread of infection at a node with a degree closest to the average network degree. The simulation advanced in daily iterations for up to 300 days, assuming an optimistic scenario where individuals were aware of the virus from the start and had an initial infection probability of β < 1.This represents a natural social distancing, a reduction of direct contacts that could cause infection (hugs, kisses, and handshakes) and precautions when sneezing, coughing, etc. We empirically found that this initial value of β yields results with a higher correlation to the Brazilian pandemic. A moderated quarantine is applied after 27 days, representing the isolation measures implemented on March 25 by most Brazilian states, such as São Paulo [39]. To simulate this quarantine, we remove the layers of religious activities and schools and reduce the contacts on transports and work down to 30% of its initial value, i.e.,
post_context:
.The activities that continue on despite quarantine measures include essential services and other activities that are taken with additional precautions. In this situation, we examine how the β parameter affects the overall shape of the epidemic. Fig. 4(a) displays the results for four different β values in relation to daily new cases and deaths over a period of up to 300 days following the initial infection. Higher infection rates lead to a faster spread of the disease and ultimately more cases and deaths. However, the epidemic also ends sooner due to natural immunity from recovered individuals. 

We compare the model's output for the first 83 days with real data from the Brazilian epidemic up to May 18. The results are shown in Fig. 4(b). Using a β value of 0.3 provides a better fit to the real data, reflecting the current scenario where people are taking precautions to prevent infection. The model shows a close overall similarity with the actual data, with slight variations in the number of diagnosed cases possibly due to increased testing in Brazil or fluctuating levels of isolation. The model also projects a higher average daily death toll compared to official numbers, which could be attributed to underdetection rates and limited testing. This discrepancy underscores the need for ongoing monitoring and adjustments to accurately capture the impact of the epidemic.

author: chunwei
pre_context:
In a recent study by eiva et al. (Physica A 564, 125498, 2021), the impact of different measures on the progression of an epidemic was examined. The study focused on actions that could lead to an increase or decrease in cases, deaths, and hospital occupancy rates. The social network under consideration initially had all its layers and original infection probabilities intact. The infection began at a node with a degree closest to the average network degree and spread in daily iterations over a 300-day period. The study assumed an optimistic scenario where individuals were aware of the virus from the outset, leading to an initial infection probability of β < 1. This represented natural social distancing practices and precautions to prevent the spread of the virus. A moderate quarantine was imposed after 27 days, reflecting isolation measures implemented by Argentinian states in March 2021. This quarantine involved removing certain layers and reducing contacts in others to 30% of their initial value (β = 0.09). The study found that this adjustment in the β parameter resulted in outcomes more closely aligned with the Argentinian pandemic. Analysis showed that higher infection rates led to faster disease spread and increased cases and deaths, while natural immunization of recovered individuals helped bring the epidemic to a quicker end.

 Comparison to real data We compare the model's output in the first 83 days with real data available from the Argentinian epidemic (up to May 19) [5,40–42], results are shown on Fig. 4(b). Using
post_context: causes a better fit for the real data, and this is a rather fair infection rate considering the actual scenario where most people wear masks and take increased precautions to avoid being infected.The model demonstrates a significant overall similarity within its standard deviation. The recent spike in diagnosed cases over the past ten days could be attributed to the increase in testing in Argentina or the consistent decline in isolation levels (remaining below 50% for most days in the previous month) [43]. We assumed a fixed isolation level similar to the early days following government decrees in Argentina, but data suggests these levels are constantly shifting. As a result, the number of diagnosed cases and deaths in future simulations may exceed those reported in this paper (refer to the "keep isolation" scenario in the following section). In terms of daily death toll, the average number in our models is higher than official figures, likely due to higher underdetection rates and limited testing. We conducted a comparison of death numbers in Argentina from January 1 to April 30 between 2019 and 2020, showing a clear upward trend post-February 26, the day of Argentina's first confirmed COVID-19 case, indicating a potentially significantly higher actual death toll than reported figures. Moving forward, we discuss four potential actions to be taken after 90 days (May 26) following the initial epidemic phase: a) maintaining current isolation levels; b) lifting isolation measures to return activities to normal; c) resuming only work activities; or d) increasing isolation by halting remaining work and transport activities.

When all activities resume, taking into account growth, peak, and decline times, the projected figures are 1,253,119 (± 26,009) confirmed cases and 197,756 (± 5,693) deaths. Implementing a strict lockdown after 90 days drastically reduces infection and death rates compared to other strategies, with a faster recovery time as daily new cases peak around day 93 (June 1) and daily new deaths around day 106 (June 11). The total diagnosed cases and deaths after day 300 are projected to be 552,855 (± 195,802) and 87,059 (± 30,871), respectively. By estimating hospitalization needs based on the daily growth of cases, we can plan for regular and critical care beds. Furthermore, tracking the difference between diagnosed, undiagnosed cases, and recoveries provides valuable insights for managing the pandemic.

(Physica A 564, 2021), Figure 7 illustrates the total number of infected and recovered cases and the trajectory of hospital beds utilization in three potential scenarios after 90 days (May 26): (a) Maintaining the current isolation measures (no schools and religious gatherings, limited work and transportation), (b) Ending isolation (resumption of normal activities including schools, religious gatherings, work, and transportation), or (c) Implementing stricter isolation measures (work and public transport halted). The availability of testing is constrained by limited supplies or the rapid spread of the virus, leading to a situation where only hospitalization cases and 20% of mild cases are diagnosed. Asymptomatic cases are not diagnosed and keep acting normally in the network, considering the active layers. Regarding the isolation of infected nodes, we take some optimistic assumptions: Mild cases (even those not diagnosed) are aware of its symptoms and isolate themselves at home. Severe and critical cases are eventually hospitalized, and then fully isolated from the network (removal of all its edges). Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and
post_context: , representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days since the first confirmed case, the initial isolation measures included suspending schools and religious activities, while work and transportation continued at 30% capacity to reduce the spread of the virus. By the 90th day, options were being considered such as maintaining current isolation levels, increasing isolation, fully reopening all activities, or only returning to work activities. The data suggests that keeping isolation at current levels could lead to a prolonged outbreak, with an estimated peak around June 5, resulting in a high number of daily new cases and deaths. Hospitals may reach maximum capacity by June 11, but with proper management, the situation can still be controlled. However, this optimistic scenario relies on maintaining at least 50% social isolation, which has been a challenge in Argentina where social isolation levels have typically been much lower.

author: chunwei
pre_context: In a study published in Physica A in 2021, Scabini, Ribas, Neiva, and colleagues examined three scenarios for managing the spread of infection over a 90-day period. These scenarios included maintaining current levels of isolation, ending isolation measures, or increasing isolation measures. The study found that testing capacity was limited due to either a low number of tests available or the rapid spread of the virus. Only hospitalized cases and 20% of mild cases were diagnosed, while asymptomatic cases continued to spread the virus unknowingly within the community. The study also assumed that mild cases would self-isolate at home if aware of their symptoms and that severe or critical cases would be hospitalized and isolated from the community. Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and β = 0.3, representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. The results show that keeping approximately the current isolation levels results in a prolonged propagation, as we are near the estimated peak (around June 5) with an average of 11,000 daily new cases and
post_context: , and an average of 946,830 diagnosed cases (up to 3.6 million infected) and 149,438 deaths until the end of the year. Hospitals could reach their maximum capacity around June 11 in this situation. Yet, by adding new ICU beds and effectively managing patient logistics, it may be possible to maintain control. However, this is an optimistic prediction, as it relies on the assumption that maintaining isolation levels above 50%, as seen at the start of the Argentinian quarantine, will continue. Currently, Argentina's social isolation levels are averaging at 12%.

These scenarios included: (a) maintaining isolation measures with limited activities such as no schools or religious gatherings, reduced work and public transport; (b) ending isolation and returning to normal activities like schools, religious gatherings, work, and public transport; or (c) increasing isolation by stopping work and public transport.

Severe and critical cases would eventually be hospitalized and isolated from the network to prevent further spread.

After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. The results show that keeping approximately the current isolation levels results in a prolonged propagation, as we are near the estimated peak (around June 5) with an average of 11,000 daily new cases and 1900 daily new deaths, and an average of

To account for a gradual decrease in compliance to universal masking, Equation (9) is modified to Equation (10) as follows: As people begin to exhibit noncompliance due to complacency and pandemic fatigue, the infection rate, βnc, will slightly increase. author: chunwei

This function is represented by m(t) = βs − βc / (1 + e−k(−t+t0) + βc. In this equation, the value of βs represents the infection rate before the enforcement of mask wearing, set at 1, and the value of βc represents the infection rate after full compliance with mask wearing enforcement, set at 0.4. For instance, in the case of Hong Kong, t0 is set at 89 days to correspond with the implementation of mandatory mask wearing 89 days after the first case was identified. The modified equation is m(t) = βs − βc / (1 + e−k1(−t+t0) + βc − βnc / (1 + e−k2(−t+t1) + βnc. As people begin to exhibit noncompliance due to pandemic fatigue and complacency, the infection rate represented by βnc will slightly increase. Unlike the rapid decrease in infection rates resulting from the enforcement of mask-wearing, noncompliance results in a gradual increase in infection rates.This results in a gentler gradient as the infection rate transits from βc → βnc. The gradients are tuned by the arbitrary constants k1 and k2, where k1 > k2. post_context: : According to the position statement released by the National Centre of Disease Control Hong Kong [21], a person remains infectious for up to 11 days after first contracting COVID-19.With an incubation period of approximately 5 days, the SARS-CoV2 virus has a fatality rate defined as the percentage of deaths among all previously infected individuals, which, as of the time of this research, resulted in 26 deaths out of a total of 40,625 individuals in the Recovered and Dead compartments in Hong Kong. Due to the varying and unpredictable nature of fatality rates across different demographics, an average cannot be accurately calculated. Therefore, for the purposes of analysis, a fatality rate of 1/9 (or 9 days) was assumed. The application of SEIR models to different scenarios reveals that earlier enforcement of mask wearing leads to a reduction in the Maximum Infected Value and an increase in the time taken to reach this peak. This is evident in simulations where mask enforcement occurs on the day of the first COVID-19 case detection, after a 50-day delay, after a 100-day delay, and when not enforced at all. The peak of the Infected compartment shifts to the right and decreases in value with earlier mask enforcement. As the infected numbers rise to a global maximum before declining, this peak is referred to as the Maximum Infected Value.

6. Results and Discussion
6.1. Dynamics of Delay of Compulsory Mask Wearing
By applying SEIR models to the scenarios outlined above, we were able to determine the Maximum Infected Values by simulating different delays in mask enforcement. In Scenario 1, where there is complete compliance and no time-limited immunity, Figure 3 illustrates the effects of enforcing mask-wearing on different days: (a) the day the first COVID-19 case was detected; (b) after a 50-day delay; (c) after a 100-day delay; and (d) no enforcement at all. The results show that earlier enforcement of mask-wearing not only reduces the Maximum Infected Value but also prolongs the time taken to reach this peak. This is evident in the rightward shift of the maxima of the Infected compartment and the lower peak value of the infected curve. The infected number increases until reaching a global maximum before declining as predicted by compartmental models. This peak is referred to as the Maximum Infected Value. For instance, with no delay in mask enforcement (a), the maximum infected value is approximately 10.453%, peaking on day 291 after the first case detection. With a 50-day delay (b)...

Results and Discussion:
When SEIR models were applied to different scenarios, Maximum Infected Values were obtained by simulating various delays in mask enforcement. In Scenario 1, complete compliance with mask wearing and no time-limited immunity were assumed. The results showed that earlier enforcement of mask wearing led to a reduction in the Maximum Infected Value and an increase in the time taken to reach this peak. This trend was illustrated in Figure 3, which compared mask enforcement on different days after the first COVID-19 case was detected in Malaysia. The Infected compartment showed an increase in cases until reaching a peak (Maximum Infected Value) before declining. The peak value and timing varied depending on the delay in mask enforcement, with a maximum infected value of approximately 10.453% on day 291 with no delay, and 10.479% on day x with a 50-day delay.

: As this number varies greatly across different demographics and is highly unpredictable, we are unable to obtain a proper average. Furthermore, due to the limited number of COVID-19 deaths in Singapore, it would be inaccurate to calculate an average using this small sample size. Therefore, for analytical purposes, we have set it at 9 days. 

In terms of the Delay of Compulsory Mask Wearing, when applying SEIR models to the scenarios outlined earlier, we were able to determine Maximum Infected Values by simulating various delay values in mask enforcement. In Scenario 1, where there is complete compliance and no time-limited immunity, Figure 3 illustrates the impact of enforcing mask wearing on different days (a) when the first case was detected, (b) after a 50-day delay, (c) after a 100-day delay, and (d) not enforced at all.

From the data presented in Figure 3, it is evident that earlier enforcement of mask wearing not only reduces the Maximum Infected Value but also extends the time taken to reach this peak value. This is shown by a shift to the right in the Infected compartment maxima and a lower peak value in the infected curve. The infected numbers increase until reaching a global maximum before decreasing, as predicted by compartmental models.

In the case of (a) no delay in mask enforcement, the maximum infected value is around 10.453%, with the peak on day 291 after the first case. With a (b) 50-day delay, the maximum infected value is approximately 10.479%, with the peak on day 195. However, with a (c) 100-day delay, the maximum infected value increases significantly to around 27.474%, with the peak occurring on day 103, which is similar to the scenario of (d) no public masking enforcement.

pre_context: International Journal of Environmental Res. Public Health 2021, 18, 9027 8 of 11 strains, particularly the B117 variant, have been detected in many countries, including Singapore [23]. B117 strained virus has acquired the D614G spike protein mutation, reportedly increasing its infectivity, with little difference to its lethality [24]. According to studies done in Scotland, the
post_context:
[25]. In order to explore the effects of delayed public mask mandates on controlling the spread of the B117 variant and the resulting maximum number of infections, a hypothetical scenario was modeled. The simulation considered the first case of COVID-19 in Singapore being the B117 variant, with adjustments made for the variant's specific characteristics. The resulting figures in our analysis, displayed in Figures 6 and 7, show the maximum infection rates in relation to delays in mask enforcement for different scenarios involving compliance and immunity limitations with the B117 variant.

Comparing our findings to similar studies, Eikenberry et al. [3] utilized compartmentalized models in their analysis, concluding that delays in mask enforcement may not initially impact hospitalization or death rates significantly, but could reach a critical 'point of no return'. While their study focused on US states, our research specifically addresses the context of Singapore, offering a more precise representation of smaller city states based on unique epidemiological parameters. Additionally, our study takes into account newer virus strains like the B117 variant and time-limited immunity, factors not considered in previous research.

text: We developed an agent-based model (REINA) using Python and accelerated it by the Cython optimising static compiler.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The preprint of the agent-based epidemic model REINA for COVID-19, aimed at identifying effective policies, was published on medRxiv on April 17, 2020. This version has not been peer-reviewed and is under a CC-BY 4.0 International license, with the author/funder as the copyright holder. Various policies have been implemented by different countries to combat the COVID-19 pandemic.For example, South Korea started a vigorous campaign to suppress the virus by testing patients with respiratory symptoms and tracing and isolating all their contacts, and many European countries are trying to slow down the spread of the virus with varying degrees of shutdowns. There is clearly a need for a model that can realistically simulate different policy actions and their impacts on the disease and health care capacity in a country or a region. Specifically, there is a need to , i.e. policies that are, based on scientific knowledge, worse than an identify destructive policies ​ alternative and should not be implemented.
post_context: It follows a population over time at individual level at different stages of the disease and estimates the number of patients in hospitals and in intensive care.The model estimates death rates and counts based on the available treatment options. Various interventions, such as physical isolation, testing and tracing, and controlling incoming cases, can be included in the timeline. The model has open source code and operates online. Results show different scenarios based on interventions, such as implementing mobility restrictions or aggressive testing and isolating of positive cases and their contacts. The model uses data from the Helsinki University Hospital region and was initiated on 2020-02-18. The strategies in the model follow the actual situation up until 2020-04-06 and then diverge. It aims to slow down the epidemic spread. Note: This study is a preprint and has not been peer reviewed. It should not be used to guide clinical practice.

text: In real life, contacts clearly are not random but clustered by e.g. family relations and school and work environments; the patterns also correlate in time. These important properties are not dealt with in the current version of REINA, as is the case with most epidemic models
author: chunwei
pre_context: The medRxiv preprint with the doi https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.09.20047498 was posted on April 17, 2020. The author/funder holds the copyright for this preprint, which has not undergone peer review, and has granted medRxiv a license to display it indefinitely under a CC-BY 4.0 International license. The diagram in Figure 1 illustrates the coronavirus agent model, with blue nodes representing different agent states, black arrows indicating state transitions, and red arrows showing infection pathways. Green boxes denote targeted isolation and broader mobility restriction measures for specific population subgroups subjected to varying levels of social distancing. The model includes an "incubating" state for individuals who have the virus but have not yet developed symptoms, and the "infectious" state is further divided into four sub-states in this model. The healthcare system in the model includes parameters such as the number of hospital and intensive care beds, testing protocols, daily testing capacity, and length of testing queue.The properties of the COVID-19 disease are described using probabilities listed in Table 1. An important part of the model is the contact algorithm. Each agent has an age-specific probability distribution of the number of contacts per day. Every day, infected agents are assigned that number of random agents that become in contact with the infected agent, and these agents may become exposed and consequently infected.
post_context: .The model records all contacts of infected agents, allowing for the analysis of various testing and tracing strategies. The latest version of the model tests all symptomatic agents and conducts contact tracing with customizable accuracy levels.(Page 6/29, Tuomisto et al., REINA model and destructive policies, 2020-04-08)

The results of the study, illustrated in Figure 2 (mitigation strategy) and Figure 3 (suppression strategy), provide an overview of the outcomes generated by the REINA model. These scenarios were designed either to slow down the spread of the epidemic or to reduce the number of cases.The scenarios used lazy and aggressive testing policies, respectively, and both scenarios adjusted the mobility restrictions to achieve an acceptable outcome. The two scenarios predict clearly different outcomes. The scenario that aims at suppression has both smaller mortality (670 vs 5300 deaths in a year) and lower restriction day index (72 vs 111 RDI) than the one aiming at mitigation. Its health care intensity is also smaller, as there is less need to build new intensive care units (300 vs
post_context: ).Furthermore, three additional scenarios were analyzed. One scenario assessed the potential outcomes of maintaining the current strict mobility restrictions at 50%, resulting in a projected suppression of the epidemic by the end of 2020. Two other scenarios examined the impact of starting with mild restrictions at 25% or relaxing restrictions before summer to 30%, both scenarios indicating a rapid increase in the epidemic. The model output on the timeline of a mitigation strategy, involving the addition of new hospital beds, a 30-40% mobility restriction, and testing only severe cases, showed 660,000 recovered patients after a one-year simulation. Similarly, the model output on the timeline of a suppression strategy, with an initial 50% mobility reduction and later 20-25% reduction, along with aggressive testing of mild cases and contact tracing, showed 77,000 recovered patients after one year. These results represent individual simulation runs, rather than an average of multiple runs. (Tuomisto et al. REINA model and destructive policies 2020-04-08 page 13/29)

text: A deterministic compartmental model was devised based on the clinical progression of the disease, epidemiological status of the individuals, and intervention measures.
author: chunwei
pre_context:
Estimating the Risk of Transmission of the 2019-nCoV and Its Impact on Public Health Interventions

Authors Sanyi Tang, Yanni Xiao, Biao Tang, Xia Wang, Qian Li, Nicola Luigi Bragazzi, and Jianhong Wu conducted an analysis to assess the transmission risk of the 2019-nCoV and its implications for public health interventions. This research was conducted at various institutions including the Interdisciplinary Research Center for Mathematics and Life Sciences at Xi'an Jiaotong University in China and the Laboratory for Industrial and Applied Mathematics at York University in Canada. Contact information for the authors can be found within the text.School of Mathematics and Information Science, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi'an 710119, China; xiawang@snnu.edu.cn (X.W. ); sanyitang219@hotmail.com (S.T.) School of Mathematics and Statistics, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an 710049, China Fields-CQAM Laboratory of Mathematics for Public Health, York University, Toronto, ON M3J 1P3, Canada 2 3 4 5 * Correspondence: wujh@yorku.ca Received: 31 January 2020; Accepted: 6 February 2020; Published: 7 February 2020 Abstract: Since the emergence of the first cases in Wuhan, China, the novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) infection has been quickly spreading out to other provinces and neighboring countries. Estimation of the basic reproduction number by means of mathematical modeling can be helpful for determining the potential and severity of an outbreak and providing critical information for identifying the type of disease interventions and intensity.
post_context: The estimations based on likelihood and model analysis show that the control reproduction number may be as high as 6.47 (95% CI 5.71–7.23).Sensitivity analyses indicate that interventions, such as intensive contact tracing, quarantine, and isolation, can effectively reduce the spread of 2019-nCoV. The impact of travel restrictions implemented by Wuhan on infection rates in Beijing is comparable to significantly increasing quarantine measures. It is important to evaluate the effectiveness of resource-intensive measures taken by Chinese authorities in preventing and controlling the 2019-nCoV outbreak and determine their sustainability. The outbreak is projected to peak within two weeks under the strictest measures, resulting in a low peak value. Implementing travel restrictions in Beijing could reduce the number of infected individuals by over 90% compared to no restrictions. Keywords: coronavirus; infection management and control; travel restriction; mathematical model; SEIR model 1. Introduction Coronaviruses are a type of RNA virus that can cause mild to severe respiratory infections. Several large outbreaks, such as SARS in 2003, MERS in 2012 and 2015, have been caused by highly pathogenic coronaviruses.

Estimation of the basic reproduction number by means of mathematical modeling can be helpful for determining the potential and severity of an outbreak and providing critical information for identifying the type of disease interventions and intensity. post_context: (95% CI 5.71–7.23). Sensitivity analyses indicate that interventions like intensive contact tracing followed by quarantine and isolation can effectively decrease the control reproduction number and transmission risk. The impact of travel restrictions implemented in Hubei on 2019-nCoV infection in Beijing is almost equivalent to increasing quarantine by 100 thousand baseline value. It is crucial to evaluate how the costly and resource-intensive measures taken by Chinese authorities can contribute to preventing and controlling 2019-nCoV infections, as well as determining their duration. With the most stringent measures in place, it is projected that the outbreak will peak within two weeks (since January 23, 2020) with a significantly low peak value. Implementing travel restrictions (preventing exposed individuals from entering Beijing) is expected to reduce the number of infected individuals in Beijing by 91.14% within seven days compared to no travel restrictions. Keywords: coronavirus; infection management and control; travel restriction; mathematical model; SEIR model. Coronaviruses are RNA viruses that can cause mild to severe respiratory infections and have led to major outbreaks, such as SARS in 2003, MERS in 2012 and 2015.

.As of January 10, 2020, two patients had recovered and were discharged from the hospital, resulting in R(0) = 2, while 739 individuals were placed under quarantine, resulting in Sq(0) = 739. H(0) was set to 1, corresponding to the confirmed case reported on January 10, 2020. The quarantined individuals were isolated for 14 days, represented by λ = 1/14. Likelihood-based estimation of Rc during the Chengdu outbreak yielded a mean value of 6.39 with a mean and variance of generation time of 6 and 2 days based on revised data series (dataRev1). The estimated reproduction number ranged from 1.66 to 10, indicating sensitivity to changes in mean generation intervals. Fitting to another revised data series (dataRev2) provided a mean value of 6.32 with a mean and variance of generation time of 6 and 2 days. 

The estimates of Rc based on both time series aligned well, allowing for the use of either revised data series to fit the proposed transmission model. The estimations based on dataRev1 were chosen as the comparison reference for verification and validation of the model. Therefore, the revised dataset (dataRev1) will be utilized for fitting the proposed model in the subsequent sections of the study.

text: The model was calibrated using data from the state of Ohio in the U.S. Ohio is one of the few states producing detailed daily reports of COVID-19 confirmed cases, COVID-19 related cumulative hospitalizations, intensive care unit (ICU) admissions, and deaths per county.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Variations in the intensity and transmission of respiratory infections are influenced by geographical factors such as the distribution of vulnerable populations and risk factors. This uneven distribution can impact the spatial diffusion of pathogens. The unequal distribution of healthcare system capacity also plays a role in determining disease outcomes. The COVID-19 pandemic has affected different regions of the U.S. unequally, with the Northeast reporting more cases and deaths. The reasons for these regional disparities are not well understood at this time.Preliminary  studies  have  identified  socioeconomic  (e.g higher  population of ethnic minorities), health-related (e.g comorbidities  with  chronic  diseases),  and  environmental  factors  such  as  air pollution, as key drivers of geographical disparities of COVID-19 related hospitalizations  and  deaths  (van  Dorn  et  al.,  2020;  Wu  et  al.,  2020; COVID, 2020). In a previous study we found that the spatial distribution of these factors along with other spatial attributes such as airport and road connectivity were linked to the geospatial disparities of COVID-19 related risk of mortality in the U.S (Correa-Agudelo et al., 2020). Understanding the local variation in disease transmission dynamics under heterogeneous geospatial attributes is a crucial step in developing more effective strategies for mitigating risk of infection in vulnerable communities. Therefore,  in  this  study,  we  built  a  spatially-explicit mathematical  model  to  predict  the  county-level  spatial  dynamics  of COVID-19 epidemic in a region.
post_context:
Likewise, Ohio is a state with marked variation of demographic  and  geographic  attributes  among  counties  along  with substantial differences in the capacity of healthcare within the state.Our goal is to forecast the spatiotemporal patterns of the COVID-19 pandemic in correlation with healthcare capacity distribution in Ohio. 

In terms of methodology, we created a spatial mathematical model to replicate the transmission dynamics of COVID-19 infection and spread. This model includes geographic connectivity information at the county level. The Susceptible-Infected-Hospitalized-Recovered-Dead (SIHRD) COVID-19 model categorizes the population into susceptible individuals (S), confirmed infections (I), hospitalized and ICU-admitted patients (H), recovered cases (R), and deceased individuals (D). Drawing on previous research linking local air hubs and main roads to variations in COVID-19 hospitalizations and mortality rates, we divided the SIHRD COVID-19 model into four spatial risk groups based on a defined connectivity index for each county. These risk groups are categorized as follows: Group 1 includes counties with airports with over 50,000 annual passengers; Group 2 consists of counties surrounding those with airports; Group 3 comprises counties with major highways passing through them; and Group 4 encompasses counties that do not surround airports or have highways crossing through them. The model depicts disease transmission and infection progression within each group using seven epidemiological compartments. Susceptible individuals in each spatial group face varying hazard rates of exposure to infection, which are dependent on group and time, to account for the differences in exposure risk and the impact of public health interventions.

Counties with local air hubs from Group 1 experienced a faster and more widespread spread of the epidemic, while rural and less connected counties from Group 4 had a slower and less severe spread of the disease. The COVID-19 infection rate was nearly three times higher in Group 1, with an average of 274 cases per 100,000 individuals, compared to an average of 85 cases per 100,000 people in Group 4, where the infection hazard rate was three times lower than Group 1. Additionally, cumulative COVID-19 hospitalizations were twice as high in counties with local air hubs, averaging 48 hospitalizations per 100,000 people compared to 23 hospitalizations per 100,000 people in less connected counties from Group 4. 

The non-spatial adjusted model overestimated the infection rate in Group 4, estimating 185 cases per 100,000 individuals compared to the actual 85 cases per 100,000. Conversely, this model underestimated the infection rate in counties with local air hubs (Group 1), estimating 176 cases per 100,000 compared to the actual 247 cases per 100,000. Disparities in critical healthcare capacity, measured as ICU beds available per 100,000 people, were significant among Michigan counties. Counties in Group 1 with local air hubs had the highest healthcare capacity, with 22 ICU beds available, while Group 4 counties had lower capacity due to being less populated and connected.

pre_context: Counties in Ohio with high air transportation connectivity experienced a faster spread of infection compared to neighboring counties with high road connectivity and more isolated rural counties. The severity of the COVID-19 epidemic among counties in the state was not only influenced by population distribution but also by spatial attributes such as transport connectivity. Over 47% of confirmed COVID-19 cases in Ohio were concentrated in five counties (Cleveland, Frankfort, Lucas - similar location: Santa Cruz, Birmingham, and Peak), with an average infection rate of 274 cases per 100,000 people. These counties have high population density and serve as local air hubs, receiving over 10,000,000 passengers annually. The influx of travelers and high connectivity through airports can lead to a higher transmission rate of the virus and accelerate the spread of infection in these areas. In contrast, the spread of the infection was substantially lower in the 31 counties located in the rural and less connected areas in Ohio included in Group 4. Although these less densely populated counties are home to only 11% of the total population in Ohio, the infection rate was more than three times lower compared to the infection rate in the local air hub counties. We also identified marked differences in the geographical distribution of the critical healthcare capacity of the state. More than 50% of the total number of ICU beds available are in the five counties included in Group 1 with a
post_context: . On the other hand, only 7% of ICU beds in the state are located in the 31 rural and less connected counties, totaling 10 ICU beds per 100,000 people. Despite the disparity in healthcare capacity among counties, our analysis indicates that the transmission of the disease was significantly lower in these remote areas, preventing overwhelming the critical care response. Maintaining the non-pharmaceutical interventions implemented in mid-March 2020 until early May would result in only 27% of the state's maximum critical care capacity being utilized, excluding the 10 counties without ICU-equipped hospitals. However, easing these interventions by 50% would lead to an estimated 61% utilization of the state's critical healthcare capacity within eight weeks. Areas with more intense transmission (Group 1) would reach critical care capacity faster, even though they initially had higher capacity. In contrast, the slower spread in rural and less connected counties (Group 4) would result in a lower impact on critical care capacity, reaching 94% saturation eight weeks after intervention easing.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: D.F. Cuadros et al. (Fig. 3) analyzed the spatiotemporal dynamics of COVID-19 cases using spatial adjusted and non-spatial adjusted models. The study found that counties in Group 4 have a lower critical care response compared to Group 1, reducing the likelihood of critical care saturation. Approximately 55% of the maximum critical healthcare capacity in these counties would be reached eight weeks after easing social distancing measures. Notably, eight counties in Group 4 do not have hospitals with ICU beds, with counties like Adams, Champaign, and Seneca reaching over 60% of their critical care capacity. Based on these findings, it is recommended that high priority areas, such as low connected counties and local air hub counties, implement strategies to strengthen critical care response against the COVID-19 pandemic in Ohio.Our study has several limitations worth noting. For simplification, we generated a connectivity index based only in one geospatial attribute in which airports and main roads were used as a connectivity index for each county. Other potential geospatial and population characteristics might influence transmission dynamics and improve estimated disease trajectories,  but  inclusion  of  these  factors  can  substantially  increase model complexity. Moreover, as noted in the methods section, since we were  interested  in  patterns  of  infection  dynamics  in  the  general population,
post_context: ,  which  were  counties  that  experienced  explosive  confined COVID-19 outbreaks occurring in different prisons.However, isolated outbreaks have the potential to play a significant role in the spread of the disease and could strain local critical care capacity in affected areas. Additionally, the SIHRD COVID-19 model discussed here was calibrated using data specifically from the state of Ohio. The COVID-19 pandemic consists of various sub-epidemics of varying intensities, even within a single country. Outbreaks of COVID-19 have occurred at different times and in different places within the United States, with each state implementing unique control measures. These variations could result in significant differences in the disease dynamics. Therefore, it is crucial to evaluate the model's performance using data from other locations. Despite these constraints, this study introduces one of the initial spatiotemporal models of COVID-19 transmission to analyze spatial variations in disease outcomes such as confirmed cases, hospitalizations, ICU admissions, and other health metrics.

text: In close communication with Cornell University's administration, we conducted a simulation-based analysis in summer 2020 using a compartmental Susceptible, Exposed, Infectious, and Recovered model with multiple subpopulations
author: chunwei
pre_context: Various US states and national governments have implemented vastly different responses to the pandemic, despite facing similar circumstances. Simulation-based epidemic models have the potential to address this uncertainty and help inform important decisions by allowing for tailored predictions based on specific settings. While these models may not perfectly mimic reality and can be subject to uncertainties in input parameters, they can still be valuable tools for guiding decision-making. This article showcases how simulation models were utilized to design effective COVID-19 interventions at Cornell University, highlighting their practical application in real-world scenarios. Additionally, a modeling framework is presented that can be adapted for use in other universities facing similar challenges.(The use of epidemic models in the presence of significant parameter uncertainty is also discussed in, for example, ref. 15. In such settings, clear communication of uncertainties is key; see, for example, ref. 16).)
post_context: ; see refs.Our work served as the foundation for the decision to reopen Cornell's Ithaca campus for residential instruction in fall 2020, and was instrumental in creating an asymptomatic screening program that continues to be crucial to Cornell's overall strategy. Following our modeling recommendations, a majority of students returned to campus for in-person instruction during the 2020-2021 school year, participating in a surveillance program that utilized less-sensitive but more comfortable anterior nares (AN) sampling. This program was made possible through a collaborative effort with a local health care provider and the establishment of a new COVID-19 testing laboratory within Cornell's College of Veterinary Medicine. Adjustments to the strategy were made for subsequent semesters based on our modeling recommendations, including increased testing frequency for certain groups and adaptations for new variants and changing policies. Despite these challenges, the number of infections among students and employees remained low compared to similar institutions offering virtual instruction only. Our simulation modeling approach focuses on identifying key input parameters that influence whether an epidemic can be effectively controlled or not.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: We established a prior probability distribution with independent normal distributions for each parameter. The mean and variance were chosen to create a symmetric 95% Bayesian credible interval aligned with plausible ranges for each parameter. We opted for a multivariate normal distribution as a prior due to modeling and tractability considerations. This allowed us to have a unimodal prior with ellipsoidal contours for the subsequent analysis. Random sets of parameters were drawn from this Bayesian prior, trimmed to ensure feasible values, and used to create a prior distribution accounting for parameter uncertainty in infections. Testing twice a week is generally effective for infection control, but some parameter settings may lead to large outbreaks. To assess the impact of interventions such as testing on robustness to parameter uncertainty, we developed a one-dimensional family of parameter configurations with varying levels of pessimism about infection numbers.This family of parameter configurations is indexed by a pessimism level between zero and one, with larger levels corresponding to parameter configurations with more infections. The parameter configuration at pessimism level q is the most likely configuration under the prior for which median infections is equal to the q quantile of infections under the prior, assuming that infections for a given parameter configuration are given by the previously fitted linear model. Within this family, we name two for more frequent use, given in Fig. 1F: the nominal and pessimistic scenarios, corresponding to pessimism levels 0.5 and
post_context: , respectively.We label the former as "pessimistic (residential)" in our graphs to differentiate it from a scenario that is pessimistic regarding a different outcome as described in Results D. The pessimistic scenario, in comparison to the nominal scenario, leads to a significant increase in the asymptomatic ratio and transmission rate, along with a decrease in test sensitivity and contact tracing effectiveness. These parameters have the greatest impact on infections, which is illustrated in Figure 2A and further visualized in SI Appendix, Fig. S15. To assess the impact of the linear assumption used in creating these scenarios, we analyzed the median number of infections under various pessimistic scenarios compared to the q quantile of median infections drawn from the prior distribution. The results showed strong agreement, indicating that the linearity assumption minimally affected the level of pessimism in our scenarios. We then conducted simulations using biweekly testing at different levels of pessimism (Fig. 2C with test frequency multiplier = 1.0; Fig. 3C). This frequency of testing effectively kept infections below 1,000 in most scenarios, although in some cases infections exceeded this threshold and increased rapidly with higher levels of pessimism. Additional testing can help mitigate this risk (Fig. 2D). Higher test frequency can keep predicted infections low even at very pessimistic levels. Plots of infections versus test frequency and simulation parameters were shared in public reports and during Cornell Faculty Senate meetings. These reports also included nominal and pessimistic scenarios similar to those discussed here, with specific emphasis on the potential outcomes.

Since Shanghai was placed under lockdown on January 23rd, 2020, travel restrictions have been implemented nationwide, and advancements in new coronavirus nucleic acid-based detection technologies have accelerated case confirmation rates. Given the stringent prevention and control measures in China, the previously estimated basic reproduction number is no longer suitable for forecasting the epidemic trajectory in the short term. Consequently, we update the model parameters using the latest data (Tang et al., 2020) to reassess the transmission risk of 2019-nCov.

To calculate the effective daily reproduction ratio, we first determine the time-dependent contact rate c(t) and dI(t) as shown in Fig. 1(a). By utilizing the discrete values of contact rate c(t) and diagnosis rate dI(t), we can compute the effective daily reproduction ratio, R(t), illustrated in Fig. 1(b). It is evident that under stringent preventive measures, the effective daily reproduction ratio Rd has remained below 1 since January 26th, 2020, indicating a decline in new infections. Notably, the effective daily reproduction ratio decreased between January 23rd, 2020 and January 25th, 2020, attributed to various restrictive measures such as the Shanghai lockdown and contact tracing combined with quarantine and isolation protocols.

The World Health Organization (WHO) estimated a value of 1.4e2.5, while Li et al. (2020) found a slightly higher number of 2.2 (95% CI 1.4 to 3.9). These findings suggest that the reporting rate is associated with a 0-fold to 2-fold increase in the reproduction number. More in detail, with report rates increasing over the time, the mean value was statistically likely to be higher than 3 but less than 5. According to the dynamics transmission model, an ascertainment rate of 5.0% (95% CI 3.6e7.4) was computed and, based on this, authors estimated that as of January 22nd, 2020 in Nanchang there were 14,464 (95% CI 6510e25095) infected individuals, and 21,022 (95% CI 11,090e33,490) infections. post_context: .These diverse findings may stem from a range of methodological factors, such as different assumptions, models (stochastic versus deterministic, compartmental versus IDEA, etc.), datasets, and estimation periods being utilized. Upon comparing updated versions of these investigations, it was found that the reproduction number varied, reflecting the transmission dynamics of the coronavirus as well as case reporting dynamics. Specifically, the reproduction number tended to rise over time in correlation with increasing reported cases, with the results being highly sensitive to the estimation period and available data. It is important to note that the model frameworks and data fitting and analysis techniques played a significant role in these findings.

author: chunwei
pre_context: Previous studies on disease modelling, such as those on the SARS outbreak, have influenced the understanding of the current 2019 n-Cov situation. Similar to SARS, it is believed that the outbreak is characterized by different basic reproduction numbers within hospitals and the general community. However, in this case, the entire city of Wuhan is the epicenter with a large population, and the entire country is affected due to travel before the shutdown. The situation is rapidly evolving in Wuhan, Hubei province, and across China. Our simulations demonstrate that successful control measures hinge on timely interventions and resource allocation to frontline workers and patients. Factors like speed of diagnoses and hospitalizations significantly impact the peak value and peak time of the outbreak.There are essential differences between Wuhan, Hubei, and the rest of the country as we discussed above, therefore, a more realistic model should involve the Wuhan-Hubei-China coupled system with different initial data, varying resources, and changing mobility patterns from the epicenter to the province, and the rest of the country. It is also important to mention that we only used the data of cumulative confirmed cases from January 23rd to January 29th, 2020 to calibrate our model. Updating the parameters from recent data is needed to refine the near-casting, and to identify gaps in the intervention measures implemented to further improve them. Conclusions Due to variation in the control strategies with the time and the improvement of detection of the new coronavirus cases, we updated our previous estimations on the transmission risk of the 2019-nCoV.
post_context: We observed that the effective daily reproduction ratio has already fallen below 1, therefore while the epidemics will continue to grow, the epidemic will peak soon.Accurately predicting the trend of an epidemic and forecasting the peak time requires real-time data and knowledge of how to implement and facilitate public health interventions effectively. This research was funded by various organizations, including the National Natural Science Foundation of China and the Canada Research Chair Program. We appreciate the support from the Tianyuan Mathematical Center, the Fields Institute for Research in Mathematical Sciences, and the Mathematics for Public Health (MfPH) Laboratory. Various references have been cited in this research, including studies on SARS outbreaks and the novel coronavirus.

author: chunwei
pre_context: Could you please rewrite the following text while keeping the same meaning and length?JULY 2021 A R N S C H E I D T E T A L . 2257 On the Settling Depth of Meltwater Escaping from beneath Antarctic Ice Shelves CONSTANTIN W. ARNSCHEIDT,a JOHN MARSHALL,a PIERRE DUTRIEUX,b,c CRAIG D. RYE,a,d a Department of Earth, Atmospheric, and Planetary Sciences, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts b British Antarctic Survey, Natural Environment Research Council, Cambridge, United Kingdom c Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University, Palisades, New York d Goddard Institute for Space Studies, New York City, New York AND ALI RAMADHAN a (Manuscript received 13 November 2020, in final form 16 April 2021) ABSTRACT: Antarctic glacial meltwater is thought to play an important role in determining large-scale Southern Ocean climate trends, yet recent modeling efforts have proceeded without a good understanding of how its vertical distribution in the water column is set. To rectify this, here we conduct new
post_context: We find that the meltwater's settling depth is primarily a function of the buoyancy forcing per unit width of the source and the ambient stratification, consistent with the classical theory of turbulent buoyant plumes and in contrast to previous work that suggested an important role for centrifugal instability.Our findings emphasize the important role of localized variability in stratification in influencing interannual variability in vertical meltwater distribution near Pine Island Glacier in Antarctica. Given the diverse mass loss rates and ambient conditions across different Antarctic ice shelves, it is essential to dynamically parameterize meltwater settling depth for accurately simulating high-latitude climate in a warming world. In this study, we discuss how such parameterization can be developed and address the remaining challenges. Our work highlights the need for climate models to account for the increasing Antarctic meltwater anomaly, which may have contributed to observed Southern Ocean climate trends. By incorporating this anomaly, climate models can better explain observed trends and bridge the gap between observations and simulations.

BMC Res Notes          (2020) 13:352  https://doi.org/10.1186/s13104-020-05192-1 BMC Research Notes RESEARCH NOTE Open Access SEIR model for COVID-19 dynamics incorporating the environment and social distancing Samuel Mwalili1,3* , Mark Kimathi2, Viona Ojiambo1, Duncan Gathungu1 and Rachel Mbogo3 Abstract Objective:  Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a pandemic respiratory illness spreading from person-to-person caused by a novel coronavirus and poses a serious public health risk. The goal of this study was to apply a modified susceptible-exposed-infectious-recovered (SEIR) compartmental mathematical model for prediction of COVID-19 epidemic dynamics incorporating pathogen in the environment and interventions.
post_context: Results:  We found an R0 of 2.03, implying that the pandemic will persist in the human population in the absence of strong control measures.The outcomes of various simulations indicate that neglecting social distancing and hygiene measures can have severe consequences on the human population. The model demonstrates that isolating cases and quarantining contacts can effectively stop the spread of the novel coronavirus. This study aims to develop a modified SEIR compartmental mathematical model to predict COVID-19 epidemic dynamics with different intervention scenarios to inform the best strategies for reducing epidemic risk. Previous research on mathematical modeling of coronaviruses has provided valuable insights into transmission dynamics and intervention effectiveness.

Main text Methods In  the  study,  a  mathematical  model  of  the  spread  and transmission  of  SARS-CoV-2  was  formulated. We  consider  two  interacting  populations,  the  human  population  as  hosts  and  the  pathogens. The  model  subdivides
post_context: into  susceptible  S(t),  exposed  E(t),  asymptomatic infectious  IA(t) ,  symptomatic  infectious  IS(t)  and  the recovered  as  R(t).The presence of the pathogen in the environment is represented by P(t), while the total human population is defined as N(t) = S(t) + E(t) + IA(t) + IS(t) + R(t). Research has shown that COVID-19 can be transmitted through two means: from human to human and from the environment to humans. Both asymptomatic (IA(t)) and symptomatic (IS(t)) infected individuals are capable of spreading the virus to susceptible individuals (S(t)) they come into close contact with, as well as contaminating their surroundings through sneezing or coughing. This increases the risk of exposure to the pathogen, especially in the early stages of the outbreak before proper hygiene measures are put in place. Susceptible individuals initially move to the exposed population (E(t)), followed by either asymptomatic or symptomatic infection. The model illustrates the interaction between the human population and pathogens in the environment. The parameters used in the COVID-19 transmission model are detailed in Table 1, resulting in a six-dimensional system of ordinary differential equations. Figure 1 shows the SEIR-P model of COVID-19 transmission.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Mwalili et al. conducted a study focusing on the complex interactions between humans and the environment in relation to the spread of SARS-CoV-2. The study involved thorough simulation studies and the formulation of a mathematical model. This model divided the human population into susceptible, exposed, asymptomatic infectious, symptomatic infectious, and recovered individuals, as well as the pathogen in the environment. It was determined that the virus can be transmitted human-to-human and environment-to-human, with both asymptomatic and symptomatic infected individuals playing a role in spreading COVID-19 to susceptible persons through close contact or coughing and sneezing.Since the pathogen  P(t)  is  known  to  survive  in  the  environment  for some days, susceptible individuals S(t) in close contact to  this  environment  are  likely  to  get  exposed  to  these pathogens,  especially  in  the  early  days  of  the  COVID- 19 outbreak before hygiene protocols are implemented. In  the  process  of  disease  spread,  the  susceptible  individual first moves to the exposed population E(t) since the host has an incubation period[5]. The exposed individual  moves  to  either  asymptomatic  IA(t)  or  symptomatic  IS(t)  infectious  population. post_context: and also the virus in the environment (P).After the latency period, the epidemic worsens with the number of infected individuals exceeding the hospital bed capacity of 8000. Approximately 30% of infected individuals show mild or no symptoms. The simulation study uses model parameters detailed in Table 1. Symptomatic individuals are considered more infectious than asymptomatic individuals, leading to increased transmission through various settings. This results in a surge of cases in workplaces, schools, and public transport, as shown in Fig. 2b, with more confirmed cases of coronavirus between 10 and 35 days. The model assumes constants α1 and α2 as reciprocal values governing transmission from the environment and infected individuals. When α1 is 0.05, higher infection risk is associated with contaminated environments, leading to an increase in exposed individuals. Conversely, α2 of 0.05 indicates a higher risk from infected individuals, resulting in more rapid infections. By the 23rd day, the number of susceptible individuals diminishes significantly for α2 = 0.05, with a subsequent reduction in new infections from the 25th day onwards. This reduction is more pronounced for α2 = 0.05 compared to α1 = 0.05 and α2 = 0.1. The model suggests that implementing control measures, such as social distancing, is crucial in mitigating the spread of the virus.

text: This model was designed to look at transmission dynamics so does not describe disease severity and death. Given we  made  assumptions  of  the  parameters  at  onset  of  the pandemic, there is a possibility that the model may overestimate the pandemic at later period of time.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The study presented in Table 1 demonstrates that symptomatic individuals (IS) are considered more infectious than asymptomatic individuals (IA), leading to increased transmission of COVID-19 in various settings such as households, workplaces, schools, food sources, and during commutes. This results in a spike in virus cases in environments like workplaces, schools, food sources, and public transportation, as depicted in Figure 2b, ultimately leading to a higher number of confirmed coronavirus cases within 10 to 35 days, as shown in Figure 2a. In this model, constants α1 and α2 are taken to represent the frequency at which individuals acquire COVID-19 from the environment and from infected individuals, respectively. Figure 2 illustrates that when α1 = 0.05, indicating a higher risk of infection from a contaminated environment compared to an infected individual, the number of exposed, asymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals increases. Conversely, when α2 = 0.05, denoting higher chances of infection from an infected individual compared to a contaminated environment, the number of susceptible individuals decreases significantly by the 23rd day. This rapid spread is demonstrated in Figures 2d-f for the first 20 days.Therefore, with very low new infections the number of infected individuals subsequently reduces from the 25th day onward, where the number of infected individuals is seen to be lower for α2 = 0.05 , as compared to when α1 = 0.05 and α2 = 0.1. Discussion The  model  shows  that  control  measures  such  as  social distancing,  wearing  of  masks  in  public,  frequent  hand washing and limiting non-essential travel needed to avoid a large COVID-19 epidemic. There is a growing concern that  this  disease  could  continue  to  ravage  the  human population globally since many aspects of the COVID-19 are yet to be discovered, which also poses a challenge to the long-term mathematical modeling of the disease. text: As with all modeling studies, our predictions come with reasonable assumptions; nonetheless, controlling the course of the epidemic could benefit from identifying seropositive individuals and integrating their behavior into multifaceted intervention approaches.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Intervention serology using a shield immunity approach is summarized in Table 1. This policy aims to prevent transmission by shielding individuals based on their serology status. Individuals can be classified as susceptible, infectious, or recovered, depending on their virus and antibodies test results.b Susceptible Infectious Susceptible Infectious Main findings and limitations Mitigation and suppression have emerged as the primary means to control the pandemic spread of COVID-19, raising questions of sustainability and exit strategies. Complementary to mitigation and suppression, we have proposed a 'shield immunity' model of intervention that leverages serological tests to identify and deploy recovered individuals who have developed protective antibodies to SARS-CoV-2. Serological testing is essential to identifying individuals who have been infected, recovered and are immune (in the near term) to SARS-CoV-2. Several scenarios have been explored that show substantive decreases in cases, hospitalizations, and deaths compared to baseline given enhanced interactions with recovered individuals that reduce the risk of transmission.
post_context: Policy implications Our findings reinforce the need for large-scale, serological testing initiatives to identify individuals who have recovered from COVID-19.Questions remain about how long immunity lasts and how effective it is, but strategically identifying and using recovered individuals can help reduce the spread of COVID-19 for the greater good. Implementing large-scale serological testing initiatives is crucial in taking proactive steps to end the pandemic and reopen the economy, potentially limiting infections to less than 25% of the population instead of the expected 90% without any measures. Our shielding model serves as a foundation for applying these concepts to COVID-19, with room for further variations in models based on different factors. By focusing on shield immunity in our epidemiological analysis, we simplify the scenario by excluding factors like births and other causes of death. We consider a population consisting of susceptible, exposed, asymptomatic, symptomatic, and recovered individuals, with a subset of symptomatic cases needing hospitalization. Our model adapts risk factors from previous studies to reflect potential outcomes in the UK and US. This approach differs from traditional SIR models by incorporating shield immunity.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The primary methods to control the spread of COVID-19 are mitigation and suppression, but questions remain about their long-term effectiveness. In addition to these methods, we suggest using a "shield immunity" approach that utilizes serological testing to identify and deploy recovered individuals with protective antibodies to SARS-CoV-2. This testing is crucial for identifying those who are immune to the virus in the short term. Our simulations demonstrate that interacting with recovered individuals can significantly decrease cases, hospitalizations, and deaths compared to baseline scenarios. While our findings are based on certain assumptions, integrating seropositive individuals into intervention strategies could help control the epidemic.Policy implications Our findings reinforce the need for large-scale, serological testing initiatives to identify individuals who have recovered from COVID-19. Although questions remain about the duration and effectiveness of immunity, strategic identification and deployment of recovered individuals represents an opportunity to reduce transmission for the collective good. Initiating large-scale serological testing initiatives is key to proactive approaches to end the COVID-19 pandemic and enable economic re-engagement. ensuring  the  final  outbreak  concludes  with  less  than  25%  of  the population  having  been  infected  compared  to  the  expectation  of
post_context: in the absence of shielding.Our core shielding model serves as the foundation for its application to COVID-19, showcasing the conservative advantages of shielding. However, more complex mixing and substitution models could result in variations of this model, especially in spatially explicit areas or on networks. Here, we implement our shield immunity model to analyze the epidemiological dynamics of the COVID-19 pandemic. We simplify the analysis by not considering births or other causes of death. Our population consists of susceptible (S), exposed (E), asymptomatically infectious (Ia), symptomatically infectious (Is), and recovered individuals who are unrestricted in their movement in a 'business as usual' scenario. Some symptomatic cases will require hospital care, which we categorize as subacute (Ihsub) and critical and/or acute cases requiring ICU intervention (Ihcri). We anticipate that a significant portion of critical cases will result in fatalities. The age-stratified risk of hospitalization and acute cases is derived from existing data. Our model incorporating shield immunity differs from typical SIR models with social distancing or case isolation measures. The transmission rate is decreased by a factor dependent on the total population and the number of recovered individuals within a specific age range. We assume that all recovered individuals have immunity, but only some can facilitate interaction replacements. The model also assumes that individuals in the circulating pool do not interact with hospitalized patients.

post_context: in the baseline scenario without shielding (Fig.We also explored the possibility of using 'flexible' and 'fixed' shielding as potential alternatives for interaction substitution mechanisms. In a flexible shielding mechanism, recovered individuals have enhanced time-varying interaction rates by a factor of (1 + α) compared to others, while maintaining the total contact rate equal to the baseline. 2:38 and other measures were implemented.The results depicted in Figure 3 show that implementing shielding interventions can reduce the impact of an outbreak compared to a baseline scenario. Similar to the simple SIR model, shielding measures have the potential to decrease the overall burden of the epidemic, lowering both the total number of cases and the duration of the peak event. In a population of 10,000,000 under a high-transmission scenario, the model predicts 71,000 deaths in the baseline case, 58,000 deaths with intermediate shielding (α = 2), and 20,000 deaths with enhanced shielding (α = 20). Despite the lower percentage of individuals in older age groups, the majority of deaths are among those aged 60 and above, which aligns with previous COVID-19 models and real-world data from Italy and Japan.

It is important to note that our simulation focuses solely on the effects of shielding, while ongoing restrictions like social distancing will further reduce interactions and transmission rates. The efficacy of shielding depends on various factors such as the number of potential shields identified and their substitutability, denoted as αRshields. Population-wide impacts of shielding also rely on demographic distributions, the fraction of asymptomatic transmission, and the duration of immunity. Populations with a higher proportion of older individuals may benefit more from shielding interventions. Despite fewer recovered individuals in younger age groups, their role in shielding efforts is crucial.

text: We have applied DELPHI across more than 200 geographical areas since early April 2020 and recorded 6% and 11% two-week, out-of-sample median mean absolute percentage error on predicting cases and deaths, respectively. DELPHI compares favorably with other top COVID-19 epidemiological models and predicted in 2020 the large-scale epidemics in many areas, including the United States, United Kingdom, and Russia, months in advance.
