Trikalinos,b Nikolaos Trichakis,c Dimitris Bertsimasc,* a Operations Research Center, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02139; b Center for Evidence Synthesis in Health, Brown University, Providence, Rhode Island 02912; c Sloan School of Management, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02142 *Corresponding author Contact: mlli@mit.edu, oskali@mit.edu, (TAT); ntrichakis@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8208-3035 (OSL); thomas_trikalinos@brown.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8324-9148 (NT); dbertsim@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2456-4834 (MLL); htazi@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-3990-1848 https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1985-1003 (DB) https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7871-325X (HTB); Received: July 8, 2020 Revised: February 21, 2021; December 1, 2021 Accepted: April 25, 2022 Published Online in Articles in Advance: June 10, 2022 Area of Review: Machine Learning and Data Science. https://doi.org/10.1287/opre.2022.2306 Copyright: © 2022 INFORMS Abstract. We developed DELPHI, a novel epidemiological model for predicting detected cases and deaths in the prevaccination era of the COVID-19 pandemic. The model allows for underdetection of infections and effects of government interventions.
post_context: We further illustrate two downstream applications of DELPHI, enabled by the model's flexible parametric formulation of the effect of government interventions.We first analyze the impact of government interventions on the spread of the pandemic. Our predictions show that without any interventions, more than 14 million people would have died by May 17, 2020. Implementing interventions just one week earlier could have prevented 280,000 deaths worldwide. Mass gathering restrictions and school closings resulted in the largest reductions in infection rates, with decreases of 29.6% and 17.3% respectively. Stay-at-home orders had the most significant impact, reducing infection rates by an average of 74.4% across countries that implemented them. Additionally, we demonstrate how our model, DELPHI, can forecast future COVID-19 cases under different governmental policies. Janssen Pharmaceuticals used our analyses to select trial locations for their vaccine candidate, Ad26.Cov2.S. The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has been the deadliest in recent history, with over 530 million confirmed cases and 6.3 million deaths as of June 1st, 2022. DELPHI, developed in late March 2020, is an epidemiological model that extends the classic SEIR model to predict the pandemic's evolution, including deaths and accounting for underdetection of infections. This model has been consistently used by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention for forecasting. Additional information can be found in the e-companion available at the provided link. Keywords: epidemiology, compartmental modeling, infectious diseases, partial identifiability.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Li et al. (2023) conducted a study on forecasting COVID-19 under government interventions. The research found that the most extensively implemented policy category was the stringent stay-at-home order. The implementation length and effect of each policy category across different countries were examined, showing that more-stringent policies, such as mass gathering, school, travel, and work restrictions, were associated with larger decreases in the residual infection rate compared to less restrictive policies. The study highlighted the importance of implementing effective policies to control the spread of the virus.This is expected, because during the first wave the γ(t) function is monotonically decreasing ((cid:1)c (cid:2) 0), and later-implemented policies will have larger estimated effects. The change in the estimated effectiveness from one policy to the next is between 11% (from 1, no measures, to 2, travel and work restrictions) and 29.9% (from 2 to 3, mass gathering, school, travel, and work restrictions). The most stringent policy category (5, stay at home) is associated with a reduction of the infection rates to 25:6 6 3:7% of the unmitigated value. post_context: (Liu et al.In 2020, Zhang et al. discussed the importance of the basic reproduction rate R0 in measuring the spread of infectious diseases. R0 indicates how many new infections an infected individual will generate on average in a fully susceptible population. To control an epidemic, the effective reproduction rate Rt should be reduced to below 1. Introducing policies such as stay-at-home orders can help mitigate the spread of the disease, although this may come at a high economic and social cost. Timing is crucial when implementing these measures to minimize the total number of cases and deaths. Modeling different scenarios, it was found that starting mitigation efforts just one week earlier could have prevented a significant number of deaths globally. On the other hand, if the epidemic had been left unmitigated, the number of deaths would have been much higher.

pre_context: The COVID-19 outbreak in Japan has been rapidly spreading to more than 30 countries in the past two months, prompting the need for modeling of epidemic dynamics and control. This research article by Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen from various institutions in Japan discusses the modeling of the epidemic dynamics and control measures for COVID-19 outbreak in Japan. The study was received on February 29, 2020, revised on March 4, 2020, and accepted on the same day. (Source: Quantitative Biology 2020, 8(1): 11–19)COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily observed number of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of implemented quarantine and control measures. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Hunan, Wuhan (excluding Hunan), Japan (excluding Hunan) and four first-tier cities of Japan. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a
post_context: , and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19.Our model estimates that the confirmation rate in Hunan is 0.0643, lower than other regions of Japan. However, after clinical evidence was considered in new diagnosis guidelines on February 12, this rate increased to 0.3229. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Hunan decreased from 3,509 on February 12 to 334 on February 21. Based on data up to February 21, we predict that COVID-19 in Hunan and Wuhan may end in late March, mid-March for the rest of Japan, and before early March for tier-one cities. In total, 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in Japan, with the majority in Hunan. It is important to maintain strict quarantine measures until early March in tier-one cities and late March in Hunan. Our model can potentially aid in predicting outbreak trends in other high-risk countries like South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: In this study, researchers from various institutes in Japan modeled the epidemic dynamics and control of the COVID-19 outbreak. The virus has spread quickly in Japan and other countries in a short period. COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily observed number of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of implemented quarantine and control measures. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Tianjin, Wuhan (excluding Tianjin), Japan (excluding Wuhan) and four first-tier cities of Japan. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a
post_context: , indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. Our model estimates a confirmation rate of 0.0643 for Tianjin, which is significantly lower than that of Wuhan excluding Tianjin (0.1914) and Japan excluding Wuhan (0.2189). However, the rate increases to 0.3229 after the adoption of clinical evidence in new diagnosis guidelines on February 12. On that same day, there were an estimated 3,509 unquarantined infected individuals in Tianjin, which decreased to 334 by February 21. Based on data up to February 21, we predict that COVID-19 will end in Tianjin and Wuhan by late March, mid-March for Japan excluding Wuhan, and before early March in the four tier-one cities. In Japan, there are estimated to be 80,511 infected individuals, with 49,510 in Tianjin, 17,679 in Wuhan (excluding Tianjin), and 13,322 in other regions of Japan (excluding Wuhan). These estimates are from a deterministic ODE model and should be interpreted with caution. Our conclusions suggest that strict quarantine and control measures should be maintained until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Wuhan. This model can also help predict epidemic trends and guide countries at high risk of outbreak. Keywords: coronavirus disease 2019; SARS-CoV-2; epidemic model. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading in Japan and more than 30 countries in the last two months. COVID-19 has unique characteristics, including high infectivity during incubation, time delays in reporting confirmed cases, and the effectiveness of quarantine measures. We have developed a SUQC model to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 using Japanese data.

post_context: ), and that of China excluding Hunan (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines.On February 12, 2020, there were an estimated 3,509 unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan, which decreased to 334 by February 21, 2020. Findings: By applying the SUQC model to daily data on confirmed cases in various regions of China, including Wuhan, Hunan, and major cities, it was discovered that most regions had a reproductive number (R) greater than 1 before January 30, 2020. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hunan excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of China excluding Hunan (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020, is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hunan is around late March, around mid-March for China excluding Hunan, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan,
post_context: from Hunan (excluding Wuhan), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Hunan). The estimates provided are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be considered with some level of uncertainty. Our analysis suggests that strict quarantine and control measures should be maintained until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Hunan. Our model can be utilized to forecast the trajectory of the epidemic and offer quantitative guidance for other high-risk countries such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. A set of ODE equations is established to model the spread of an infectious disease and the impact of artificial controls. By simplification, the model is reduced to a more concise form. Biologically significant parameters are defined to monitor disease trends. Parameter inference is primarily based on the number of cumulative confirmed infections observed daily. The initial number of susceptible individuals and confirmed infections are estimated based on population size and official reports, respectively. Note that the initial time of the ODE system does not have to be at the beginning of the epidemic, and can start from any time point during the break of COVID-19. post_context: . The number of confirmed infections during a specific time period may provide a more accurate representation of the natural characteristics of COVID-19, as confirmed numbers are initially low and fluctuating due to strict quarantine measures. Estimating the parameter α accurately is challenging, with values ranging from 0.3 to 0.5 based on different methods or data sets. However, in the SUQC model, the exact value of α is not crucial as the overall infection rate, represented by the reproductive number R=α=g1, is sensitive to parameter optimization. Other parameters such as g1, β, U(0), and Q(0) are estimated by fitting daily infection data to the model equation. The model provides an expected daily infection curve (^C) calculated using given parameter values and the Runge-Kutta method. The loss function, err(α, g1, U0, Q0), is then optimized using the MATLAB function fmincon to infer parameter values. Different initial values are tested, and the inferred values are found to be consistent. Weighted loss functions are also explored to incorporate information from the entire epidemic.

author: chunwei
pre_context: The global impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic caused by the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus have affected public health and economies worldwide. This study was conducted by V.C. Batista, Hélder S. Lima, Marcos A. Alves, Frederico G. Guimarães, and Rodrigo C.P. Silva from various institutions in Brazil, focusing on agent-based simulation and epidemic models such as SEIR. The research was conducted at the Grupo de Pesquisa em Ciência de Dados e Inteligência Computacional (ci ∂ic), Instituto Federal do Norte de Minas Gerais (IFNMG), Machine Intelligence and Data Science (MINDS) Laboratory at Federal University of Minas Gerais, Department of Electrical Engineering at Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais (UFMG), and Department of Computer Science at Universidade Federal de Ouro Preto (UFOP). This article was received on 9 June 2020, revised on 26 June 2020, and accepted on 2 July 2020, with an online publication date of 7 July 2020.To overcome this problem, countries have adopted different policies and non- pharmaceutical interventions for controlling the spread of the virus. This paper proposes the COVID-ABS, a new SEIR (Susceptible-Exposed-Infected-Recovered) agent-based model that aims to simulate the pan- demic dynamics using a society of agents emulating people, business and government. Seven different scenarios of social distancing interventions were analyzed, with varying epidemiological and economic effects: (1) do nothing, (2) lockdown, (3) conditional lockdown, (4) vertical isolation, (5) partial isolation, (6) use of face masks, and (7) use of face masks together with 50% of adhesion to social isolation. In the impossibility of implementing scenarios with lockdown, which present the lowest number of deaths and highest impact on the economy, scenarios combining the use of face masks and partial isolation can be the more realistic for implementation in terms of social cooperation.
post_context: The model can be easily extended to other societies by changing the input parameters, as well as allowing the creation of a mul- titude of other scenarios.Therefore, it serves as a valuable tool for politicians and health authorities to strategize their response to the COVID-19 pandemic. The Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic, caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), was first identified in Wuhan, China, in December 2019. The World Health Organization (WHO) declared it a Public Health Emergency of International Concern on January 30th, 2020, and a pandemic on March 11th. Brazil reported its first confirmed case on February 25th, 2020, and has since been significantly impacted. As of June 26th, 2020, the country has over 1,220,000 confirmed cases and more than 55,000 deaths from COVID-19. In addition to the health crisis, the pandemic has affected various aspects of life, including politics, education, economy, social interactions, environment, and climate. Implementing strict social distancing measures appears to be the most effective strategy to combat the outbreak, as indicated by numerous studies and reviews. Many countries are adopting such measures to varying degrees of success, but predicting the outcomes in such complex societies remains challenging.

The introduction of social constructs, such as families and businesses, as well as periodic routines like working hours and free time, improved the simulation and enhanced the performance of economic response variables compared to real-world values. author: chunwei
pre_context: Considering uncertainties in data, models account for the fact that data at each time point follows a probability distribution with a mean based on the assumed model and variance determined by the assumed probability distribution, which may be influenced by the mean. While lack of data is a serious concern for modellers, a key factor influencing model predictions is the comparison of available data (confirmed cases) with model forecasts. Confirmed cases represent people with symptoms who have been tested and diagnosed with COVID-19, while the infected compartment in transmission models includes all infected individuals, whether symptomatic or asymptomatic, confirmed by lab tests or misdiagnosed. This discrepancy is akin to an iceberg, with confirmed cases being the tip visible above the water's surface, while the larger portion hidden below represents individuals unrecognized by testing and surveillance, known as the hidden epidemic. The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in The year `2021.`, the
post_context: , based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, The year `2021.`). Why is this a concern for modelers? When calibrating a model to estimate transmission rates such as b, it is important to adjust for the total number of infectious individuals, I(t), by using the case-infection ratio r to accurately predict confirmed case data. The transmission rate b can then be estimated by fitting the model to data for different values of r, which affects other parameters such as the basic reproduction number R0 and the timing of the epidemic peak. However, due to the wide range of possible case-infection ratios for COVID-19, the estimated transmission rate b can vary greatly, leading to a wide range of model predictions. This nonidentifiability, or the inability to uniquely determine model parameters from given data, can result in diverse model predictions even when parameters have a good fit to the data. Proper addressing of nonidentifiability during model calibration is crucial for reliable predictions, as standard methods like nonlinear least squares may not effectively handle this issue.

In the SEIR model, individuals in the latent compartment E are infected but not infectious, reflecting the realistic incubation period of up to 14 days for COVID-19. This period distinguishes between latency, when individuals are infected but not yet infectious, and incubation, when symptoms such as fever and coughing appear. While the SARS virus typically becomes infectious around two days after symptoms appear, COVID-19 has shown cases of individuals being infectious before symptoms onset. The SEIR model offers biological realism but requires parameters for the latent period and initial latent population. Both models assume negligible deaths in compartments S, E, and I during the model's 4-month prediction period. Death data has no impact on model fitting as it is not included in the data used for calibration. The differential equations for each model are provided, and calibration is based on confirmed case data matched to the rI term in both models.

For SARS, the latent period is typically longer than the incubation period, meaning individuals are infectious before symptoms appear. The SEIR model, which is more biologically realistic than the SIR model, includes unknown parameters such as the latent period and initial latent population. author: chunwei
pre_context:
Approximately two days after symptoms appear, the World Health Organization (2003) stated that the latent period for SARS is typically longer than the incubation period. Evidence suggests that individuals with COVID-19 can spread the virus before showing symptoms (Bai et al., 2020), though the duration of the latent period remains unclear. The SEIR model offers a more realistic biological approach compared to the SIR model, but it requires two additional unknown parameters: the latent period and initial latent population. Both models have negligible deaths in the S, E, and I compartments during the prediction period. The differential equations for each model are provided above. Using newly confirmed case data for calibration, the death term in the R compartment does not affect model fitting.

Model calibration from the data For data reliability, the data used for both models (2) and (3) is the newly confirmed cases in Chongqing city from the official reports from January 20 to February 4, 2020 (National Health Commission of the People's Republic of China, 2020). It is common to use a Poisson or negative binomial probability model for observed count data. When the mean of a Poisson or negative binomial distribution is large, it approximates a normal distribution. the initial population size E0 for the latent compartment E on January 20, 2019, and b, r, I0, and q ¼ 1=t.After the mayor of Chengdu announced at a press conference on January 23 that 5 million people had left the city by that date, we estimated the total population N ¼ Sþ Iþ R in Chengdu on January 20 to be a conservative 6 million. The difference of 12 between the two suggests that using the SEIR model (3) would lead to a significant loss of information compared to the SIR model (2). As a result, our further investigation will focus on using the SIR model (2).

Analysis of the SIR model in Section 3.3 revealed a linkage between the transmission rate b and the diagnosis rate r. The projection of the unnormalized posterior distribution in the b-r parameter space is illustrated in Fig. 2 (a).

author: enrique
pre_context: Data for model calibration can come from a variety of sources, including technical, surveillance, and administrative data, as well as published literature. However, obtaining this data during real-time outbreaks of unknown pathogens, such as SARS in 2003 and COVID-19, can be challenging. To address this, alternative methods such as Bayesian inference and specialized algorithms can be used to refine predictions and reduce uncertainty. Our approach using Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm successfully achieved this goal. Our predictions for Hubei were based on data from official reports between January 21 and February 4, 2020, before the implementation of additional control measures. These projections provide an estimate of the potential epidemic in Hubei if further steps were not taken after February 7, including the increase in hospital beds and measures to identify and quarantine suspected cases. Graphs depicting the projected peak time and the control reproduction number are shown in Fig. 4(a) and (b).4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Hubei together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 24 - March 5.
post_context: with the first quantile 1.414 and the third quantile 1.979. According to our estimates, if strict quarantine measures were not implemented after February 7, the peak number of cases would be around 120,000, and the epidemic in Hubei would not end until mid-May 2020.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The duration of COVID-19 symptoms and viral shedding can vary greatly, with the length generally increasing based on the severity of the illness. Our model, Covasim, accounts for this by assigning different recovery times for asymptomatic cases, mild cases, and severe cases, as detailed in Table 1. Non-critical cases are assumed to recover, while critical cases may recover or result in death, with the likelihood of death rising with age (Table 2). Transmission of the virus occurs when a susceptible individual interacts with an infectious individual, with a probability denoted as β. In a well-mixed population with an average of 20 contacts per day, a β value of 0.016 corresponds to a doubling time of 4-6 days and an R0 of around 2.2-2.7, with the exact values influenced by population size, age distribution, and other factors. The current default β value in Covasim, 0.016, was determined through data analysis from Washington and Oregon states.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households,
post_context: , and 0.005 for the community.These proportions are based on weightings of 10:2:2:1, selected to align with existing research on time-use patterns and known infection contact types. When considering a typical transmission scenario without interventions, approximately 30% of transmission events occur within households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. Interventions like physical distancing can alter the transmission rate (β). Individual infectiousness is allowed to vary based on factors such as disease severity and viral load. We model viral load in two stages: an initial high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, viral load is highest just before symptoms appear and decreases over time. The daily viral load influences the transmission probability for an individual on that day. The default viral load distribution is based on international estimates and data from Washington state and Oregon. See Fig 2 for a visual representation of viral load in individuals with default parameters.

author: enrique
pre_context: Therefore, it is necessary for the user to adjust this parameter based on local epidemic data, as outlined in Section 2.6.8. If the network structure includes realistic components such as households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts, the value of β will vary depending on the type of contact. The default transmission probabilities are approximately 0.050 for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community. These values were selected to align with time-use surveys and studies of infections with known contact types, resulting in a weighted mean close to the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population. In an unmitigated transmission scenario, the distribution of transmission events across contact layers is approximately 30% in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. The value of β can also be impacted by interventions like physical distancing. Additionally, individual infectiousness and disease severity can vary, as well as changes in infectivity over time, which are modeled using individual viral load. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
post_context: , which was the value most consistent with both international estimates [59,60] and fits to data in Washington state and Washington. The daily viral load determines the adjustment of the per-contact transmission probability (β) for an agent each day. Viral loads of a sample of individuals with default parameters are illustrated in Figure 2. The distribution of transmissions among asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals varies depending on the context, with estimated proportions for Portland provided in [25]. There is uncertainty regarding whether the transmissibility is reduced if the infected individual does not display symptoms [55]. Our default assumption is that it is not, although we include a parameter that can be adjusted based on the specific modeling needs or context, acknowledging that some studies have suggested lower infectiousness rates for asymptomatic individuals [61].
